botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in full sun with fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil. For best flowering apply a balanced fertiliser and mulch in late winter or early spring and a balanced fertiliser again in early summer. Tolerant of poor soils and suitable for hedging
how_to_grow.propagation: Root hardwood cuttings in autumn and bud in summer
how_to_grow.pruning: See pruning roses - rose pruning: shrub roses
how_to_grow.pests: Susceptible to rose aphid, scale insects, leafhoppers, caterpillars, rose leaf-rolling sawfly larvae and leaf-cutting bees; rabbits and deer may cause damage
how_to_grow.diseases: Prone to black spot, rose rust, rose powdery mildew, rose dieback and canker, rose balling, honey fungus, replant disease, a virus and downy mildew
